Row.Text: A white mouse leads the settlers onwards, then scurries off. The settlers follow it for days through the dense terrain. When it vanishes — here is a spring, and glass-clear water pouring from the earth. This will make a good city.
The lust for new lands drives new migrants on.

The Khmer baray have long fed the people. But in the years since the Việt took power, the sacred task of their maintenance has waned. Silt has crept in, and flat stretches of bare mud lie exposed during the dry season.
Redesign their drainage along new Việt standards.
Have Khmer priests carry out the old ritual.

The gates of Weiyang Palace lie open, its endless halls now a labyrinth. But it is not empty. Now, migrants from the countryside raise their children where princes once laid their heads, and market vendors shout their wares where courtiers once whispered. But is this correct?
Yes. It shall be a city in itself.
No. It shall be cleared and refurbished.

The newly-promoted commander lacks social graces. His áo giao lĩnh is torn at the chest, revealing skin latticed with scars. But none points this out, even when he is not present. Rumored by Đại Việt’s enemies to be everywhere and nowhere at once, none dare.
His star will rise higher still.
He will advise the war effort from above.
The Lake of the Returned Sword
At the war’s end, the Việt commander is rowing in the lake, by the capital. A turtle, he recounts, surfaced and asked for the commander’s sword — it was not of the human realm, but divine.
When scholars write, they use a script that, while beautiful, does not match the Vietnamese language. Inspired, they turn towards their neighbors. Surely they could learn something there.
Scholars design a script based on the writing of others.
Scholars continue their own way of writing.

Diplomats congregate in the Forbidden City; believers in {1_Religion} worship in Notre Dame, and the citadel of Hue guards all. The poets ask — what did Đại Việt do, to so merit the blessings of the gods?
It is a long chain of coincidence that has led them here.

As the smoke rises above the conquered city, soldiers already begin to debate — will they gain a piece of the spoils? At the same time, the scions of noble families desperate for lands of their own begin to entreat the palace.
Land goes to those who fought for it.
Land goes to the noble families.
Land remains in the hands of the original citizens of {1_STORY_CITY}.

A noble is fishing in the lake near the capital when a fog arises. The shadow of a boat emerges… and the silhouette of a tiger! Thinking quickly, an attendant captures the beast in a net, whereupon it becomes a court mandarin.
Release him to his teaching duties.

The Mongol occupying forces march into the conquered city, and Việt townspeople eye them warily from doorways and windows. How deep will this occupation go? How long will it last? In {1_Capital}, the Việt leaders consider their grudges.

Trung Trac’s figure cuts through the marketplace, her fierce expression fixing onlookers in place, as her sword whirls around her body. Her face, though, is that of an old woman — this is a medium, who claims that her spirit has been replaced by Trung’s.
This is sedition. Ban the practice.
This is an honor. Find a place for it.
A small boat’s departure seems minor, but it will raise winds and storm when it reaches the world.[n] The Tale of Kiều
The Good Doctor and the Water Puppets

Standing at the edge of a flooded rice field, Dr Rizal watches a water puppet troupe rehearse a challenging sequence. Soon enough, entire flocks of birds have come to life at the ends of bamboo sticks.
Speak with the farmers about their practices.
Speak with the performers about their training.
